verbs.description: By E.J. DIONNE JR . WASHINGTON -- [ARGM-TMP: By now] , [ARG0: we] [V: know] [ARG1: that President Trump is a lying demagogue . Since] this is not said often [ARG1: enough , he has been allowed to routinize] lying and enshrine the vilest forms of divisiveness as a normal part of our politics . Lies do not deserve deference just because a president tells them . We thought that the media learned during Joe McCarthy 's heyday that " We report the lies , you decide " is not a responsible approach to journalism . Trump 's egregiousness requires everyone to take a refresher course in the lesson of McCarthyism . At the same time , just calling out deceit is insufficient . It is essential as well to understand why Trump tells particular lies at particular moments and to be hardheaded in judging how effective they are . This is a precondition to turning back the smears and the falsehoods . Trump 's address Tuesday at a Nashville rally was a lollapalooza of deception . He kept the fact - checkers busy . PolitiFact raised doubts about 15 of his statements and flatly rated 10 of them as " mostly false , " " false , " or " pants on fire . " But two passages are worth special attention . " They do n't want the wall , they want open borders , " Trump said of ...
